subject: Re: [junit] Re: Expected exception pitfall and pattern

messageBody:
On 30/11/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
> Indeed. I used to do that a lot, but now I don't. I think I found that
> all those custom exception classes weren't worth the effort.

I don't have that many... in general, state capture is a fairly
generic problem, and I don't need to have lots of custom exceptions to
solve the issue.

I capture enough state to be able to do something meaningful with the
error - for example, to turn it into a string for display given a
template. This means I need an error identifier, and arguments that
can be turned into Strings. So a base exception that has an identifier
property and a list of properties is sufficient... like this:

public class SuperGenericException extends Exception {
private long identifier;
private List<Object> state;

public SuperGenericException(long id, Object ... params) {
identifier = id;
state = Arrays.asList(params);
}
...
}

Heavy use of custom exceptions doees not require lots of exception classes.
